bestBHT.bht: When Jesus knew in himself that his disciples were stumbling over his words, he sought to help them understand. He revealed that if they were struggling with what he had said thus far, they would find it even more difficult to comprehend what he was about to say. He acknowledged that his teachings might expose the hidden doubts and unbelief that they harbored in their hearts. Jesus desired to address their concerns and reassure them. Just as Jesus knew their thoughts, he knows our hearts and invites us to come to him for understanding when we find his teachings challenging or perplexing.

Henry Alford: 61.] in himself, by His divine knowledge.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If ye are stumbled at what I have said, how will ye bear what I now say?
Not that His ascension itself would stumble them more than His death, but that after recoiling from the mention of the one, they would not be in a state of mind to take in the other.
they would not be in a state of mind to take in the other.
Marvin Vincent: Offend [οκανδαλιζει] . Rev., cause to stumble. See on Matthew 5:29. Wyc., slandereth you.
John Calvin: the doctrine does not so much wound them as it exposes the putrid ulcer which they inwardly nourished in their hearts.
thus we ought to repress the wickedness of those who, urged on by nothing but the rage of mastiff dogs, slander the word of God
when we do not immediately perceive the Lord’s meaning, there is nothing better than to go straight to him, that he may solve all our difficulties
Philip Schaff: Doth this make you to stumble?" - Jesus, knowing in himself that his disciples murmured concerning this, said unto them, Doth this make you to stumble?
He knew their thoughts." - He knew their thoughts, and because they are disciples, not Jews bent on opposing Him.
He seeks to help them." - He seeks to help them.
Archibald T. Robertson: Knowing in himself...for this supernatural insight into men's minds."
Cause to stumble...for which see Matthew 5:29.
John Gill: When Jesus knew in himself... being the omniscient God..." (Quote 1)
Does this offend you? or trouble you? cannot you get over this? cannot you understand it?" (Quote 2)
If not, how will you be able to digest some other things, or reconcile them to your minds, which are less known, and more unexpected, and will appear at first sight more surprising?" (Quote 3)

bhtAttempts.bht: When Jesus knew in himself that his disciples were stumbling over his words, he sought to help them understand. He revealed that if they were struggling with what he had said thus far, they would find it even more difficult to comprehend what he was about to say. He acknowledged that his teachings might expose the hidden doubts and unbelief that they harbored in their hearts. Jesus desired to address their concerns and reassure them. Just as Jesus knew their thoughts, he knows our hearts and invites us to come to him for understanding when we find his teachings challenging or perplexing.

Jesus, being the omniscient God, knew in himself that his disciples were stumbling over his words. He asked them if his teachings were causing them offense, recognizing that if they were troubled by what he had said so far, they would struggle even more with what was to come. Jesus understood that his words had the power to expose the doubts and skepticism hidden within their hearts. He wanted to help them grasp his teachings and urged them to seek him for clarity and understanding.

Jesus understood that his words had the power to expose the doubts hidden within their hearts. He wanted to help them understand and encouraged them to seek him for clarity and understanding.

Jesus, knowing in himself that his disciples were stumbling over his words, questioned if his teachings were causing them offense, understanding that if they were troubled by what he had said thus far, they would struggle even more with what was to come. He recognized that his words had the ability to expose the doubts hidden within their hearts. Seeking to assist them, he encouraged them to turn to him for guidance and clarity in comprehending his teachings.

Knowing in himself that his disciples were stumbling over his words, Jesus questioned if his teachings were causing them offense, as he understood that if they were troubled by what he had said thus far, they would struggle even more with what was to come. Jesus acknowledged that his words had the power to expose the doubts hidden within their hearts. Seeking to help them, he encouraged them to seek him for guidance and clarity in understanding his teachings.
